questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is a selective alpha 1 receptor antagonist?
questions.explanation:
Prazosin is a sympatholytic drug that is a selective  1 receptor antagonist. The sympatholytics are classified into  and -blockers. 136 
Sold by @itachibot Miscellaneous antiadrenergic drugs that inhibit synthesis or release of neurotransmitters include: • Metyrosine • Reserpine • Tetrabenazine • Deutetrabenazine

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding prazosin?

options.a: Blocks all subtypes of alpha 1 receptors
options.b: It is only an arteriolar dilator
options.c: It has a beneficial effect on lipid profile

questions.explanation:
Prazosin causes dilation of both arterioles and veins. As a result, both afterload and preload decrease. However, the reflex tachycardia is less 
pronounced due to the absence of  2 blockade. Prazosin blocks all subtypes of the  1 receptor ( 1A,  1B, and  1D). It also has a beneficial effect 
on lipid profile as it decreases LDL and triglycerides and increases HDL levels.

questions.question: Question 3: In which of the following patients would prazosin not be used therapeutically?
questions.explanation:
Prazosin is not useful to treat a patient with ejaculatory dysfunction. It is indicated in relieving 
symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Prazosin is an  1 receptor antagonist and is useful in: • Relieving vasospasm in peripheral vascular diseases • Controlling the symptoms of pheochromocytoma preoperatively (as an alternative to 
phenoxybenzamine) • Mainstay treatment for scorpion sting along with antivenom 137 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient presents with complaints of dizziness while getting up from bed. He tells you he was 
recently diagnosed with BPH and has been taking prazosin. Which of the following drugs 
would be a good replacement for him?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of postural hypotension caused by prazosin. These symptoms can 
be avoided by using silodosin which has a selective antagonist action on  1A receptors over  1B 
receptors. The prostate stroma has a maximum concentration of  1A receptors over other  1 receptor 
subtypes.  1B receptors are present on blood vessels which play a role in vasoconstriction. Hence, 
selective  1A receptor antagonists have minimal effect on blood pressure as compared to 
non-selective  1 antagonists like prazosin.  1 receptor antagonists can be classified as: • Selective antagonists • Silodosin ( 1A) • Tamsulosin ( 1A +  1D) • Non-selective • Prazosin • Terazosin • Doxazosin • Alfuzosin

questions.question:
Question 5: A 62-year-old male presents with complaints of a weak urine stream and frequent urination 
in small amounts for the past month. He also mentions that he often feels lightheaded and 
has low blood pressure. Which of the following alpha-blockers will you prefer to give him?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and tamsulosin should be 
given to this patient as it has the least effect on blood pressure. It is an  -blocker that has more selectivity towards  1A/1D when compared to  1B receptors. The 
vasodilatory effects are mainly attributed to the blockade of  1B receptors present on blood 
vessels. The relief of BPH symptoms is mainly due to the blockade of  1A receptors present 
predominantly in the prostatic stroma. It lacks the apoptotic effect on prostatic cells that is seen 
with terazosin and doxazosin.

questions.question:
Question 6: You prescribe tamsulosin to a patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia. What is the main 
side effect that should be explained to the patient?
questions.explanation:
Retrograde ejaculation is the main side effect of tamsulosin. It is a selective  1A/1D blocker and the relief of BPH symptoms is mainly due to blockade of  1A 
receptors. Blockade of  1D receptors present in the bladder relaxes the urethral sphincter, which 
is normally closed during ejaculation. This results in the redirection of semen into the urinary 
bladder. 138 
Sold by @itachibot Silodosin causes ejaculatory dysfunction due to absence of seminal emission.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is a selective alpha 2 receptor antagonist?
questions.explanation:
Yohimbine is a competitive antagonist that is selective for  2 receptors. It was earlier used in the 
indication of erectile dysfunction but is rarely indicated now due to better results with PDE5 
inhibitors. Terazosin and alfuzosin are selective alpha 1 receptor antagonists. Yasmin (drospirenone) is a 4th generation progestin used as an oral contraceptive having 
mineralocorticoid antagonist action.

questions.question: Question 8: Phenoxybenzamine is indicated in the management of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Phenoxybenzamine is indicated in the preoperative preparation of patients with 
pheochromocytoma. It is also indicated for symptomatic control in inoperable and advanced 
pheochromocytoma. Option B: Phenoxybenzamine is not used in the management of essential hypertension because of 
the irreversible alpha blockade and increased risk of adverse effects. Option C: For erectile dysfunction, intracavernous phentolamine, a reversible non-selective 
alpha-blocker is indicated.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient with erectile dysfunction complained of unsatisfactory response to oral medication. 
He was then administered an intracavernosal injection of phentolamine following which he 
developed sustained painful erection. Which of the following can be used to reverse his 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The reversal of phentolamine induced priapism (painful erection) can be achieved by 
intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine. Intracavernosal phentolamine ( -blocker) is used for the management of impotency. Priapism is a 
serious adverse effect of this agent. Phenylephrine is an  agonist and counteracts phentolamine 
induced priapism by producing vasoconstriction. Phentolamine is useful in: • Hypertensive crisis due to clonidine withdrawal • Short term control of intra-operative hypertension in patients with pheochromocytoma • MAO inhibitor-induced hypertension in cheese reaction Options A and B: Phenoxybenzamine and prazosin are  -receptor antagonists and can worsen 
priapism. Option D: Propranolol is a non-selective -blocker and is not indicated in this condition. 139 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: In which of the following conditions is propanolol not indicated?
questions.explanation:
Propranolol is not indicated in variant angina. It can cause further constriction of coronary 
arteries by leaving alpha-mediated coronary vasoconstriction unopposed. Uses of propranolol include: • Management of thyrotoxicosis • Management of hypertension (however, cardioselective beta-blockers are now preferred over 
non-selective) • Treatment of infantile hemangioma • Management of essential tremors and panic attacks • Prophylaxis of migraine • Prevention of variceal bleeding in portal hypertension

questions.question:
Question 11: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus during a routine health 
evaluation. He mentions that he is on propranolol for essential tremors. You would caution 
him against continuing the drug due to what reason?
questions.explanation:
Propranolol is generally avoided in diabetic patients because it masks the hypoglycaemic 
symptoms. Non-selective  blockers interfere with the counter-regulatory hormones secreted during 
hypoglycemia, resulting in prolonged hypoglycemia. It also decreases the perception of symptoms 
such as tremors, tachycardia, and nervousness. These symptoms are manifested due to 
stimulation of sympathetic beta receptors in response to hypoglycemia. Blunting of sympathetic 
response results in hypoglycemic unawareness. Cardioselective beta-blockers have relatively lesser interference on the sympathetic response to 
hypoglycemia and are preferred in diabetic patients.

questions.question:
Question 12: 132 
Sold by @itachibot Propranolol is drug of choice for:
questions.explanation:
Propranolol is the drug of choice in the management of infantile hemangioma complicated by 
ulceration or in symptomatic patients. It acts by causing vasoconstriction, inducing apoptosis and inhibition of angiogenesis.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is a cardioselective beta blocker with antioxidant property?
questions.explanation:
Nebivolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker with additional antioxidant property. Nebivolol: • Nebivolol is a third-generation, long-acting, and highly selective 1 adrenergic receptor 
antagonist 140 
Sold by @itachibot • It stimulates NO-mediated vasodilation via 3 receptor agonism • Nebivolol is approved for the treatment of hypertension • It has potential utility in the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction • Nebivolol reduces oxidative stress and may have favorable effects on both carbohydrate and lipid 
metabolism • This can be used in metabolic syndrome.

questions.question: Question 14: Esmolol is indicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Esmolol is a short-acting cardioselective beta-blocker that is indicated in: • Prevention and management of intraoperative tachycardia • Postoperative hypertension • Supraventricular tachycardia • Hypertensive emergency It is contraindicated in pulmonary hypertension.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is a false statement?

options.a: Metoprolol prolongs survival in congestive cardiac failure
options.c: Esmolol is mainly metabolised in the liver

questions.explanation:
Esmolol contains an ester linkage and it is hydrolyzed rapidly by esterases in erythrocytes and not 
in the liver. This results in a short half-life of about 8-10 minutes. It is used in the management of intraoperative and postoperative hypertension as it has a short 
duration of action and can be discontinued quickly. Option A: Metoprolol is approved for use in chronic congestive cardiac failure and has shown 
mortality benefit. Option B: Celiprolol has shown a relaxant effect on vascular smooth muscle and weak vasodilation 
due to partial selective 2 agonism. Option D: Nebivolol has the additional action of releasing nitric oxide.

questions.question:
Question 16: Identify the third-generation beta-blocker that does not cause alpha 1 receptor antagonism. 133 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Celiprolol is a third-generation beta blocker having no action on  1 receptors. It causes 
vasodilation by partial selective 2 agonist activity. Labetalol, carvedilol, and bucindolol are non-selective third-generation beta blockers that possess 
additional  1 receptor antagonistic action. This is responsible for their vasodilatory effect. Note: Third-generation -blockers are those that possess additional vasodilating actions and 
include cardioselective and non-selective drugs. 141 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: You are about to add a beta-blocker to the treatment chart of a patient with heart failure. 
Which of the following is not true about the use of these drugs in this condition?

options.b: Most effective in acute decompensated heart failure
options.c: Should be started at a low dose
options.d: Carvedilol is widely used in this condition

questions.explanation:
-blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) as 
they can worsen the condition. They are indicated only in patients with chronic stable heart 
failure. Option A: Though contraindicated in ADHF, it is safe to start once the patient is euvolemic. 
Initiation of -blocker prior to discharge is associated with improved outcomes and must be 
continued after discharge. Option C: -blockers are initiated at a low dose and slowly titrated to decrease the risk of 
precipitating heart failure. Option D: Carvedilol has been shown to reduce mortality in patients with heart failure, and is 
widely used because of additional benefits like antioxidant properties and peripheral vasodilatory 
action.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is not true about beta-blockers?

options.a: Atenolol is longer acting than metoprolol
options.b: Labetalol has both alpha and beta blocking action

questions.explanation:
Celiprolol is excreted predominantly through the renal route. It is excreted unchanged in the 
urine. Option A: Atenolol is longer acting with a longer half-life than metoprolol. It is usually 
administered once daily. Option C: Labetalol is a non-selective -blocker with  1 blocking action similar to carvedilol. Option D: Nadolol has the longest half-life of 20 hours and is administered once daily.

questions.question:
Question 19: A nurse in the nephrology ward is managing the drug inventory for patients with severe renal 
failure. Which of the following beta-blockers is least likely to be present in the drug charts?
questions.explanation:
Sotalol is least likely to be present in the treatment charts as it is contraindicated in severe renal 
failure. It has low lipid solubility and is excreted primarily unchanged in the urine. Carvedilol, metoprolol and labetalol are metabolised by the liver and can be used in renal failure.

questions.question:
Question 20: Beta-blockers are not indicated in which of the following patients? 134 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Beta-blockers are not indicated in hypothyroidism. They are indicated in hyperthyroidism and 
thyrotoxicosis that manifests with increased sympathetic activity. Options B and C: Beta-blockers are useful in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal and in reducing 
variceal bleeding in portal hypertension. Option D:  blockers like propranolol are effective in controlling acute panic symptoms and 
anxiety associated with performing in public. They reduce symptoms of increased sympathetic 142 
Sold by @itachibot activity such as tachycardia and tremors.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is a selective beta 2 antagonist?
questions.explanation:
Butoxamine is a selective 2 antagonist. There are no clinical indications currently for selective 2 antagonists and they are still being 
researched.

questions.question:
Question 22: Cocaine-like effect of inhibiting neuronal uptake of noradrenaline is seen with which of the 
following?
questions.explanation: Cocaine-like effect of inhibiting neuronal uptake of noradrenaline (NE) is seen with labetalol. It is a third-generation non-selective  blocker with the following actions: • Non-selective  receptor blockade • Selective  1 receptor blockade • Inhibition of neuronal uptake of NE/cocaine-like effect

questions.question: Question 23: Match the following beta-blockers with their receptor selectivity and additional actions.
questions.explanation:
Pindolol is a non-selective first-generation -blocker with significant intrinsic agonist activity, 
which may result in a smaller reduction in heart rate and blood pressure. This is useful in patients 
with diminished cardiac reserve or at risk of bradycardia. Carvedilol is a non-selective third-generation -blocker with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory 
properties. These properties make it useful in the treatment of congestive heart failure. Betaxolol is a 1 selective third-generation -blocker with additional calcium entry blockade 
activity and a slight membrane-stabilizing property. It does not have agonist activity. Acebutolol is a 1 selective second-generation  blocker having both membrane-stabilizing and 
intrinsic agonist activity. It is useful in the treatment of atrial and ventricular arrhythmias. Pindolol 
Non-selective, intrinsic agoni

Sold by @itachibot Drugs for Glaucoma
